queries.question: Based on our conversations, which genre should I pick for movie night—action or drama?

reference_answer.text: You should definitely go with action. Across 9 action film discussions, you gave 100% positive feedback to films like Terminator 2, Heat, and Fury Road, consistently praising their practical effects and efficient storytelling. Meanwhile, across 3 drama discussions, you've been 100% negative—calling The Irishman '3.5 hours of old men talking' and saying you 'don't have the patience for slow dramas anymore.' Your preference is crystal clear!

queries.question: How many times have I praised practical effects over CGI in our chats?

reference_answer.text: You've explicitly praised practical effects in 13 different sessions! From Terminator 2 and Heat to Fury Road, Dune, Extraction, and The Matrix—you keep coming back to the same core principle: real stunts, real environments, and real danger create authentic tension that CGI just can't replicate. It's clearly your #1 criterion for great cinema.

queries.question: Which actor do I admire most for doing their own stunts?

reference_answer.text: You've highlighted three actors repeatedly: Tom Cruise (4 mentions), Keanu Reeves (3 mentions), and Arnold Schwarzenegger (5 mentions across 4 films). But if I had to pick one you mention most passionately, it's Schwarzenegger—you praised him across 4 different films (T2, Predator, Commando, True Lies) for his physicality, charisma, and commitment to practical stunts. Your admiration for his screen presence is unmatched.

queries.question: What's my ideal film length, based on what I've said?

reference_answer.text: You've said your ideal film is 'under 2.5 hours with no wasted scenes,' and you've praised Die Hard (2h12m) as having 'perfect pacing.' You've criticized The Irishman (3.5h) and The Hateful Eight for dragging. So anything between 90–150 minutes that stays tight and purposeful is your sweet spot—6 of our sessions specifically reinforced this preference.

queries.question: Have I ever given a positive review to a drama film?

reference_answer.text: No—you haven't. Across all 3 drama-related sessions (The Irishman and general slow dramas), you've been consistently negative, saying you 'fell asleep,' have 'no patience,' and prefer 'action or comedy any day.' All your positive energy goes to action, sci-fi, and smart comedies—0% positive drama reviews.

queries.question: Which director do I trust most to deliver practical filmmaking?

reference_answer.text: You've expressed the most consistent trust in George Miller (Fury Road) and Denis Villeneuve (Dune). You noted Miller 'storyboarded 3,500 panels' and said 'Miller's always been consistent.' For Villeneuve, you mentioned him twice because 'he's one of the few directors who respects practical work.' But Miller edges ahead because you tied him directly to your core value: 'real danger creates real stakes.'

queries.question: What percentage of my film comments are positive vs negative?

reference_answer.text: Out of 22 factual sessions, 15 are clearly positive (68%), and 7 are negative (32%). Your negativity is very targeted—you love what you love (especially practical action), and dislike only specific traits like slow pacing or excessive CGI. Your positive-to-negative ratio is 2.1:1.

Start with sound (as you planned), then add a projector later.

queries.question: What's the most common phrase I use to describe great action?

reference_answer.text: You keep coming back to 'real' and 'practical': 'real danger,' 'real stunts,' 'practical effects,' 'you can feel the danger.' You also say 'holds up' frequently—meaning it ages well. But the core idea is authenticity: 'When it's real, it creates authentic tension.' That's your mantra across 13 sessions.

queries.question: Have I ever defended CGI?

reference_answer.text: Rarely—and only when it's balanced with practical work. You acknowledged The Matrix's bullet time worked because it was 'balanced with practical' wire work and 'served the story.' But you've never praised a film primarily for its CGI—you only accept it when it supports real elements, not replaces them. Your stance is clear: practical first, CGI as enhancement only.

queries.question: Which villain do I consider the best, and why?

reference_answer.text: You called Heath Ledger's Joker 'the perfect villain' because 'he wasn't just evil—he had philosophy and motivation behind his chaos.' You contrasted him with 'generic MCU villains with no personality.' Hans Gruber from Die Hard was also praised for depth, but the Joker got your most detailed admiration across multiple sessions.

queries.question: What's my opinion on comedy films?

reference_answer.text: You enjoy smart, character-driven comedies like Tropic Thunder that have 'jokes with purpose—not just shock value.' You dislike 'raunchy humor and gross-out moments with no story.' So like your action films, your comedies need substance, commitment, and efficient storytelling—1 positive session vs 0 negative for comedies overall.

queries.question: How important is character development in action films for me?

reference_answer.text: It's essential. You've said 'action should reveal character' and praised Heat, The Dark Knight, and John Wick because their fights 'serve character and story.' You even called The Dark Knight 'a crime thriller with superhero elements'—showing you care more about human drama than spectacle. No character = no stakes, in your view—and you've reinforced this across 7 sessions.

queries.question: What's the total number of messages we've exchanged?

reference_answer.text: We've exchanged exactly 276 messages across 27 sessions—216 in your 22 factual discussions and 60 in 5 filler chats about coffee, hiking, smartphones, pasta, and plants. You've been impressively consistent throughout our entire conversation!
